title: Will the U.S. leveraged loan default rate reach or exceed 5.0% before 1 September 2021?
preds: No, the pump is still churning.
Basically NO. The rate is trending down and the fed is still printing tons of money.

US Congress needs to not do a stimulus but rather initiate a real primer for velocity of money. Asia is best option. Asia doesn’t like the Russians either. Most Asians don’t anyway.

It seems exceedingly unlikely that this will happen. In particular, it seems unlikely that it will be higher than at the height of the pandemic. However, I'm not 100% certain. In particular, one pathway I could see is that financial assistance declines faster than financial need. Hence my 3%.
Time update; logic; The leveraged loan default rate in the U.S. historically has averaged 3.1%. It now stands at 0.93%. LCD, an offering of S&P Global Market Intelligence
We have the Fed buying all junk available, why this will happen; if junk is available a discount rates, defaults are not going to take place while the junk gets floated.

April = 2.61
Rate increased a bit earlier in year, but is on the way back down.  Unless there is a big shock, which everyone is working to avoid, it’s unlikely to suddenly jump up.  Although it’s always possible.

No news, still 3.15% as of 31 March 2021.
Major decline for the first update of April 2021 expected, probably around 15 April at the latest.

Vaccination plan is going fast and growth projections are strong for United States (according to the IMF). It is very unlikely that this facts, which I think are explaining a lower default rate since september, are going to reverse.
Bankruptcies I was expecting to see show up in the rate haven't.
adjusting down, however, still anticipate a wave of defaults to push rate over 5% as stimulus and loans expire.

S&P Global states as of Mar 1 the baseline default rate this year at 3.5% with the pessimistic scenario taking it to 6%. I still think the spike in inflation that we will see in May could skuttle some boats.

Went up to 4pc but slowly coming down.  New stimulus package going out to keep people going.  So can’t see a dramatic increase between now and sept.  May tick up a bit and run steady but as it hasn’t got to 5pc at all over the last year, feel unlikely for this year.  Maybe next when things start to go back to normal and support beings to be withdrawn.
The 1.9T US economic rescue package and the willingness of the Federal Reserve an Treasury to quickly "bailout" massive loan defaults reduces the risk.

Gonna be just over the crowd consensus for this update for these reasons:
1) There is enough time for any anomaly to occur.
2) It took just 5-ish months to deviate 1.77 units away from where it was at the corresponding time, 1.77 being the number needed to go from the current 3.23 to 5.00.
3) If it were to climb again, it would likely reach 5 before the closing date, and the primary reason I go closer to the consensus is that I see it more likely to keep decreasing than increasing over the next several months (pandemic stimulus, vaccines, etc.).
There would need to be 9bn a month of defaults to hit that level, and there is no way Yellen and Powell would let that happen.
With stimulus package and no big uptik in Jan and February I am lowering this.
The U.S. leveraged loan default rate is expected to end 2021 at 4.76% (it is currently 3.89%). The default rate peak is expected at less than 6%.
Shifting based on the crowd forecast
Raising due to the fact that inflation will be above 2.5% within three months. The market sees this coming which is why the 10 year has been so severely shorted in the repo market the last two days.
3.23 for February. Looks increasingly unlikely especially with more stimulus likely on the way and vaccinations continuing to ramp up.

As of the end of Jan Fitch is projecting 4.5% for 2021, but it's not clear if this is the highest point they expect to reach or if this is what they expect for the year average. 
https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-us-leveraged-loan-default-insight-2021-default-forecast-lowered-to-4-5-loans-of-concern-total-falls-ninth-straight-month-28-01-2021&ved=2ahUKEwjmzqC-5-juAhUNFjQIHd7dBLUQFjACegQIExAB&usg=AOvVaw289fwQB1ob7VCj6V9uHN8u

I really don't understand why the crowd is only at 8% right now. Even without covid the US and world economy is not doing well. CPI inflation is around 3-4% over the last 4 months since we've come out of the recession (if we did). Inflation is what is likely to pop the big everything bubble we have going on. We seem to be entering into a period of stagflation.
might go as high as 6% so it depends on the moratorium on rent and whether or not people's unemployment benefits are extended so they could at least tread water
Updating due to continued downtrend in default rate (3.46% latest) and stimulus package

I give it very little change for now - same as for last year's challenge We see a decreasing slope already with Jan21 at 3.38% and given Biden admin trying to set up $1.8Tn relief package I'd find defaults on loans unlikely to sharply increase Stimulus package will still take months to pass (Senate now on impeachment) and be executed
The Democrats are pushing for cash relief checks of $1,400 and other measures should help to keep the default rates lower.

Needed to move lower but I don't know where to.   I'm still a bit high because as I understand it, that loans are being restructured rather than just bankrupted but in order for a troubled company to get their loans restructured they need to be in technical default.
More stimulus seems likely and the default rate has been going down. Seems very likely to remain below 5.
The default rate should stabilize around current levels and then decline as the Federal govt measures kick in and the economy improves.
The odds of defaults stemming from last March are now close to zero. Yet, another market downturn before September remains a threat.

Survey respondents expect loan defaults will rise over the next 12 months, from its current rate of 3.89% (as of 18 Dec), though only 29% say the peak will be at 6% or above. This marks a significant improvement from the throes of the market crash in March, when Street expectations generally called for peak default rate of 7-8%. Market participants, on average, see the default rate of leveraged loans ending 2021 at 4.76%. (After peaking somewhere below 6%) https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/blog/2021-leveraged-loan-survey-defaults-edge-higher-credit-quality-a-concern
With the AMC capital raise, and the other WSB equity squeezes, there is more capital flowing into the distressed names, so reducing again.

Leveraged loans are not all loans - they are floating rate loans typically provided by institutional investors to highly indebted (3-5x EBITDA) companies, often those backed by private equity investor groups. The current new issue debt markets are extremely ‘supportive’ - low rates, good terms, and ‘easy money’ flowing from lenders to even struggling issuers, such as energy and gaming. Often these refinancings come with equity injections to reduce leverage levels and appease lenders. In a world where vaccine roll outs give the market and investors cause for medium term optimism, there is no incentive for any stakeholder to want to push companies into bankruptcy when the 6 month outlook is potentially so much brighter. Companies, equity investors and lenders all are better off with improved performance and when businesses remain ‘going concern’ rather than insolvent.  As such, I do think this rate may have already peaked and will level out or continue to trend downward. Everyone should also go read @SE_Meyer post about how this is actually calculated and what gross default volumes are required in H1 2021 to exceed the volumes for H1 2020. That said, I am still revising my forecast to account for potentially being overconfident on a topic that has a lot of inherent uncertainty.
Powell Yellen combo unlikely to allow that
Any assistance provided by Congress will be too little, too late.

Incoming data seem to indicate that the default rate may have already peaked. Improving economic data and market sentiment suggest the near-term risk of a 5% rate is low. I'm retaining some risk that the economy will falter in the next 8 months, although that risk also appear to be getting smaller.

Using this forecast (as of 2020-10-01) from the resolution source, I assume 60/40 that the metric rises above 5%, assuming no structural change due to a recession. To create my estimate of a recession in 2021, I reviewed a wide variety of sources. I am arbitrarily picking 10% odds of a recession in 2021 and assuming this automatically triggers a very high default rate. Net expected value is 65%

The rate of default looks like it is on the downward trajectory. New Biden administration has proposed a new $1.9 trillion covid response and stimulus. With democrats controlling the agenda in both chambers of congress this plan has a shot at being voted on. But the bill would require Republic support to avoid a filibuster. 
https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/01/whats-in-joe-bidens-stimulus-package-plan.html
https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/01/will-we-get-a-third-round-of-stimulus-checks-from-biden.html Biden Treasury Secretary nominee stated at her confirmation hearing "that it’s “critically important to act now” to pass more economic relief for the coronavirus pandemic" ...  “The most important thing in my view we can do today to put us on a path to fiscal sustainability is to defeat the pandemic; to provide relief to American people; and then make long-term investments that will help the economy grow,”
https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/01/19/yellen-confirmation-hearing-stimulus/

-10 based on latest value for January, a pretty significant drop to 3.38. Default rate is already dropping and more stimulus seems pretty likely at this point, plus a significant reduction in the virus is in sight. A big sign pointing in the other direction for the economy though is unemployment numbers remain high. That said, I think prospects are pretty good for a quick recover and the default rate not exceeding 5%. Unemployment: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/UNRATE

S&P Global The U.S. leveraged loan default rate is expected to end 2021 at 4.76% (it is currently 3.89%). The default rate peak is expected at less than 6%, but the default cycle could extend for 1-2 years. Credit quality tops the list of concerns for leveraged loans in 2021.Dec 18, 2020
Improving economic news warrants a downward revision in the likelihood here. Still maintaining a cushion to account for the chance that we break the 5% threshold based on a future downturn.

Hard to tell what Biden's fiscal policy and the the Fed Reserve / Treasury will do in the coming months, I do see further stimulus on the horizon, but how long will a potential $1.5T keep the ship afloat. Leveraged Debt is at all-time highs, but defaults will only come when the cash runs out and/or inflation beats out income growth with stimulus.

I had been relying on Fitch estimates, and they just materially lowered their projections to 4.5% (https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/2021-us-loan-default-rate-in-line-with-2020-hy-trending-lower-13-01-2021). Based on the same logic as previously that would give an S&P default rate of between 3.8-4.5% (-0.7% - I am also removing the conservatism adjustment of 0.5%).
Combined with the fact that we are mid-Jan and there doesn't appear to have been any major defaults yet, I am dropping back down to my previous forecast of 12%.
I am in agreement with @SE_Meyer rationale.

The good news is that loan default defaults in Q4 came down from their high in SEP20 falling from 4.17% in Sep to 3.83% in Dec. A surge of defaults in the Oil & Gas sector and retail spurred the growth in default rates in 2020. Those markets have seemed to stablized a bit and did not see huge defaults in Q4. However, most experts see the default rate continuing to rise into 2021. The latest forecast survey from S&P Global saw 57% of respondents thinking the default number will be above 5% by year end. Although we may not see the large volume of defaults we saw from Jun-Sep last year, it is likley that a steady stream of defaults through at least Q3 pushes the rate above 5% at some point.
Interest is extremely cheap and looks to remain so. A resulting debt crisis is unlikely to change the terms of existing loans.

Ok I may have been thinking about this wrongly. Following my previous comments and along the lines of the discussion between @ForecastingNovice and @SE_Meyer, I had assumed that you would need a worsening economic environment to cause a very bad quarter of defaults, for a positive outcome to this question, as Aug20 to Dec20 had been relatively benign and this was a trailing rate. Now I am not so sure. 
The links that @SE_Meyer provided, reminded me that the individual loan items are what is important. Given the majority of loans expire in the first half any year, in H1 21 there is a high chance that we get significant defaults from Entertainment or Leisure companies, who simply won't have the cashflow to repay notionals, and bankruptcy may actually be preferable to the pretend and extend scenario I had been pushing. 
Indeed, Fitch has 40% of leisure/entertainment, 18% of retail and 9% of the healthcare/pharmaceutical loan sectors defaulting this year (https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-us-leveraged-loan-default-insight-default-activity-slows-in-november-loans-of-concern-total-declines-20-11-2020). From what I can gather their analysts have been on the conservative side, but they still see 7-8% default rate in 2021. Fitch was still predicting 4.5% for 2020 in late December, and they may have a slightly difference universe to S&P, so even haircutting their number by 0.5% for conservatism and 0.7% for the spread between the two agencies, you would still get 5.8% for the year. If these defaults were due to loans maturing as opposed to breaching of covenants (less likely), it would put most of defaults into H1 21. In the absence of any more information, I will return my forecast to the initial level of 42% until the January numbers come out, where unless there are numbers of around 5-7bn of defaults I will then drop my forecast once again.
Massive fiscal stimulus plus the fact that this is a rolling 12M stat. Trend is already moving the other way

After reading @SE_Meyer rationale, I thought I had better check my definitions, I had been operating under the basis that it was an annualised default rate, but in fact its a 12 month trailing rate (https://www.top1000funds.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Seeking-income-private-debt_MG.pdf). So with Aug20 to Dec20 having had low notional defaults, you effectively need another quarter like Q2 20 (the highest quarter since 2009) to get there . If I stay true to my belief that low rates, lite covs, monetary and fiscal stimulus and a vaccine roll-out will dampen out defaults, or at least allow a "pretend and extend" scenario, I need to drop my initial prediction materially, so going 12%, and will look to the monthly numbers to tweak.

In the latest market survey, 42% of respondents believed the default rate would peak at less than 5%. Another 29% foresee the peak below 6%.  https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/blog/2021-leveraged-loan-survey-defaults-edge-higher-credit-quality-a-concern  Because the time frame of this question extends to September, it is possible that the immediate risk peaks below 5% but the question is still yes due to future economic threats. I'd say the odds are lower than 42% in the near term, as overly pessimistic views still distort the perception. But, a real threat of a new economic downturn lingers. Therefore, I'm setting my forecast slightly higher.

No.
Revisited the "rolling-sum" concept of the"S&P Leveraged loans default rates - US$ principal amounts"
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/hertz-drives-us-leveraged-loan-default-amount-to-6-year-high-58796938
https://www.snl.com/articles/404128096.jpg Conclusion:
/at the first documented LL default of January 2021, the index will be re-calculated ("refreshed"), but then around 6bn of default sum of January 2020 will no longer be included in the rolling sum - the index will sink dramatically by around 0.36% points to 3.47%.
/If the index will not cross 5.0% in February and/or March 2021 due to major bankruptcies (> 10bn USD debt affected by a default), the same major influence from the "back end of the rolling sum" will repeat on the first default documented in April (~7bn USD as of Apr 2020) and May (~11bn USD as of May 2020).
Ceteris parisbus, the index with no additional default sum would then sink by another 0.4% (April 2021) and 0.65%(May 2021) and could thus go as low as approximately 2.5% by early summer, unless there is a documented default sum in the LL market of about 25bnUSD in total to replace last year's default sums of H1 2020. Note to myself:
Check whether the Trump Organization uses Leveraged Loans... :-)

The historical average is 2.9% and the professional portfolio managers are expecting 5.46% by the end of Jun 21. They also as a group tend to be pretty bearish once a loan loss cycle has started, and have been continuously reducing their expectations of defaults since March. 
Combining Yellen's, Powell's and Biden's stimulus plans with the vaccine rollout (the 4.17% peak was before the vaccine announcement and since then rates have come down), I will project the under. I also assume the absolute level of rates as well as the convenant-lite nature of some of these loans will allow "extend and pretend" scenarios to help the default rate. 42% to start. https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/blog/2021-leveraged-loan-survey-defaults-edge-higher-credit-quality-a-concern
https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-peak-at-6-6-8211-lcd-survey-60554195

Please checkout this S&P link[1]. They have themselves forecasted this index based on market survey and are projecting a peak default rate of 5.5% by middle of the year. [1] https://pages.marketintelligence.spglobal.com/LCD-2021-Loan-Market-Survey-Infographic-Pr2.html
As good a reason as any: https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/lcd-survey-us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-rise-to-5-3-by-year-end-59375981

Actual defaults, business closures, and bankruptcies  have remains significantly below levels implied by the unemployment rate. Results are better if you adjust for permanent vs temporary. Lower rates increase appetite for yield which will drive demand up. Further M&A in 2021, and higher stimulus probability.  Downside risk is rising inflation and rates. I think any 2021 inflation will be a head-fake but let’s watch.

It looks like it tends to shoot up and then go down according to @Ryan-Becks presenation.  It has already plateaued and things are likely to improve.  However there are multiple months where it could hit 5%, and it isn't that far from their now.

Loan managers have been wrong about the default rate prognosis in the past. From S&P Global [1]: "For year-end 2020, loan managers see the loan default rate closing out at 5.16%. This is slightly improved from a forecast in the second quarter of 5.32%." The actual leveraged loan default rate closed out at 3.83%. According to S&P Global [2], the leveraged loan default rate is expected to end 2021 at 4.76% and the peak throughout the entire cycle is expected to be a little less than 6% according to the median survey respondent, though "the default cycle could extend 1-2 years". Moreover, 42% of survey respondents believe that the loan default rate will peak at less than 5%. In light of all of this information, I make an initial forecast of 75% that the 5% threshold will be exceeded before 1st September 2021, compared to the current crowd forecast of 95%. [1]: https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/us-leveraged-loan-default-rate-expected-to-peak-at-6-6-8211-lcd-survey-60554195
[2]: https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/blog/2021-leveraged-loan-survey-defaults-edge-higher-credit-quality-a-concern

I think it's a little more likely to stay under 5%. At the pdf linked below on pdg page 3, slide 5, it shows the 2009 recession exceeded 10% at its worst, but that it climbed very fast. I still think the government response has been key in keeping things from getting too bad this time, and has been a lot more effective than in 2009. And it's likely more government relief is to come with Democratic control of Congress and the presidency. The default rate peaked a few months ago and has slightly declined. I'd guess it'll fluctuate over the next few months and probably won't really decline significantly anytime soon. But I do think there are bright signs ahead with vaccine rollout and I'm optimistic that government action has helped people weather the recession better and put them in a better position to get the economy on the right track once this is over. https://www.chicagofed.org/~/media/others/events/2010/private-equity-conference/07-21-coffey-presentation-pdf.pdf
The economy is peaking and I am anticipating a reversal in the first half of 2021.  Defaults will go up.
